column2: I‚Äôd also like to thanks @Fly666Mc who also donated freeukraine.eth to them.
@cryptophinn @ctjlewis @FireblocksHQ I‚Äôd love to hear suggestions.

Our goal is to make it safe without creating any technical burden in their side. We‚Äôre discussing solutions, including using a third party (like ensdao.eth) or some other type of contract. If anyone has some insight it would be cool to hear. https://t.co/V3S13AF6CW

Ukraine.eth was generously acquired by @KittyInuToken and I‚Äôve helped them set it up to point to the correct donation address in both ether and Bitcoin to facilitate donations.

We have not yet transferred ownership to them because it seems it‚Äôs an exchange address.

@LefterisJP @kbw We have a call set up to hear more. But it‚Äôs not as bleak: if there‚Äôs good reason to believe you did not know, then it‚Äôs unlikely that anything will happen. But if I become a director then that responsibility increases for me.

While that‚Äôs weird in a international blockchain, legal believes that in the case of a breach of sanctions, some major delegates (specially if they‚Äôre citizens of the country giving out sanctions) could potentially be personally held liable.

You were airdropped responsibility.

Regarding the ‚Äúdue diligence‚Äù I mentioned. After talking with lawyers, I would advise all delegates (and potential directors) to be more through on checking country of origin recipients with any disbursement of funds.

In the future, I wish we can find a process that allows more time hearing and empathizing and less focus on in/out group thinking and punishment.
Because the outcome now was just having stronger think bubbles and not better inter bubble cooperation.

Marshal Rosenberg, creator of Non Violent communication said: ‚ÄúPeace requires something far more difficult than revenge or merely turning the other cheek; it requires empathizing with the fears and unmet needs that provide the impetus for people to attack each other.‚Äù

Regarding the Brantly situation, I am okay with any outcome. While I abhor the things he has said, I haven‚Äôt found any anecdote that he actually acted in an intolerant way towards anybody. But most importantly i think the whole process was too fast and chaotic.

Dear ENS holders who delegate to me: This is an important week with 7 open votes.
* I will be abstaining from voting on directorship issues because I‚Äôm a candidate.
* I will probably vote in support for all budgets as soon as I do some due diligence on the recipients

@mr_ligi @LefterisJP @davebit_ @pedrouid I doubt putin wants a long prolonged and expensive war. Not saying this is the ideal outcome (see Syria for the dangers of just arming rebels and prolonging a complex conflict), but imagine what a fast victory means for him.

@mr_ligi @LefterisJP @davebit_ @pedrouid Those who don‚Äôt want to fight should be free to do so and take refuge elsewhere (including Russian soldiers who wish to desert Putin!). But those who decide to risk their own lives, deserve to have the back of the international community somehow. Putin doesn‚Äôt want a long war.

@mr_ligi @LefterisJP @davebit_ @pedrouid I think there‚Äôs a big difference between being sent to war in a foreign country for the interest of the rich, and voluntarily taking arms to defend your home. While I‚Äôm a pacifist who never touched a weapon, I respect the latter.

@elmalandr0 @Timccopeland Yes the trouble of steem was onchain governance

Don‚Äôt know why smart people keep making that mistake but even having a majority control on a PoS chain doesn‚Äôt give you free reign to do whatever you want. Having 51% control on a PoW chain doesn‚Äôt either by the way. https://t.co/OnSGQWpoaR

@balajis You can‚Äôt ‚Äúrewrite history‚Äù with proof of stake. PoS is not some kind of democracy in which they arbitrarily vote whatever they want the chain to be in the next block, it‚Äôs a rigid game in which cheating can be much more expensive than PoW.

@Jenny_Pollack @Fatalmeh @q9fmz @degen_chimp @ph_lux @MPtherealmvp @danhwang88 No doubt. Maybe we should deeply thank Toby for helping us reinforce our systems and mature the tooling for DAOs. Our computers are more secure. 

But if he had dropped it, he would have never been doxxed. That‚Äôs now his problem, not mine.
@Fatalmeh @Jenny_Pollack @q9fmz @degen_chimp @ph_lux @MPtherealmvp @danhwang88 It‚Äôs not ‚Äúgreat benevolence‚Äù to NOT to attempt to steal a hundred million dollars, it‚Äôs basic decency.

@Jenny_Pollack @Fatalmeh @q9fmz @degen_chimp @ph_lux @MPtherealmvp @danhwang88 Sure, I had the privilege of knowing a lot of people and that‚Äôs why I jumped to help. 
But he did manage to take out 30% of the DAO by himself. He could right then have announced on an anonymous account on reddit that he intended to give it back, and the community would help.
@jackbutcher Original open source tech.
@Fatalmeh @Jenny_Pollack @q9fmz @degen_chimp @ph_lux @MPtherealmvp @danhwang88 Yet, that‚Äôs what I did.
@jackbutcher Yes sir, I‚Äôve got a contender. Free to share, changed drastically all societies it arrived in, almost universally accepted in all cultures. https://t.co/34GlKPQKTa

@Jenny_Pollack @q9fmz @degen_chimp @ph_lux @MPtherealmvp @danhwang88 The hacker could‚Äôve done what we did:
* contact people privately and offer help
* exploit the code and take the money out
* immediately alert people ‚Äúthe DAO is being securely drained‚Äù to avoid market fears
* write a recovery contract that gives the money back to token holders

@degen_chimp @q9fmz @ph_lux @MPtherealmvp @danhwang88 Exactly. One conducted himself in a selfish manner to enrich themselves out of the others. The other can reasonably say he was just accidentally probing stuff and didn‚Äôt intend to cause a catastrophe (unless it turns out he had shorted eth and went looking for mayhem).
@ph_lux @MPtherealmvp @q9fmz @danhwang88 Well the guy didn‚Äôt steal anyone, he just found a big red button saying ‚Äúdon‚Äôt push this‚Äù and pressed it.

@akomba We found it when looking at his transactions. Don‚Äôt know if it made Laura‚Äôs book.
Also, that wasn‚Äôt the first attempt of the DAO hacker to attack ethereum. There was another.

I have no pity on Toby Hoenisch, if he is truly the guy. That period was stressful for all of us, we almost saw everything we had build fracture and fall.

Ether was $10 back then, ICO‚Äôs hadn‚Äôt happened yet. He could easily still be a legit millionaire and a hero. He choose it.

So in short the DAO hacker used:
* Shapeshift to convert ETC to BTC
* Wasabi to mix the BTC
* 4 Different central exchanges
* Withdrawn to Grin for added privacy

And yet he was a found. Thanks to chain analysis, insider cooperation and the hacker‚Äôs ego. It only takes one error.
@laurashin @Coinfirm_io @chainalysis And apparently a huge thanks to the anonymous exchange employee who revealed the IP address of their client üòâ
